Cutting the flowery pride on the velvet plain,
Lies down at night, and in the weary folds
Of his wives arms, forgets his labour passed.
The painful mariner, and careful smith,
The toiling ploughman, all artificers,
Most humbly yield to my dominion,
Without due rest nothing is durable.
Lo thus doth Somnus conquer all the world
With his most awful wand, and half the year
Reigns over the best and proudest emperors.
Only the nurslings of the sisters nine,
Rebels against me, scorn my great command:
And when dark night from her bedewy wings
Drops sleepy silence to the eyes of all,
They only wake, and with unwearied toil,
Labour to find the via lactea
That leads to the heaven of immortality;
And by the lofty towering of their mind,
fledged with the feathers of a learned muse,
They raise themselves unto the highest pitch,
Marrying base earth and heaven in a thought;
But thus I punish their rebellion,
Their industry was never yet rewarded,
Better to sleep then wake and toil for nothing.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 17.
div.stage: The five senses, lingua, appetitus, all asleep, and dreaming, Phantastes, Heuresis.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: So ho Rocwood, so ho Rocwood, Rocwood, your organ, hay Chanter, chanter, by Actaeon's head-tire it's a very deep mouthed dog, a most admirable cry of hounds; look here again, again, there, there, there, ah beware counter.

sp.speaker: Vis.
sp.p: Do you see the full moon yonder, and not the man in it? why methinks 'tis too, too evident, I see his dog very plain, and look you, just under his tail is a thorn-bush of furs.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: 'Twill make a fine toothpick: that lark's heel there, oh do not burn it.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Boy, Heuresis, what think'st thou I think when I think nothing?

sp.speaker: Heu.
sp.p: And it please you sir, I think you are devising how to answer a man that asks you nothing.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p:
Well gest boy, but yet thou mistook'st it,
for I was thinking of the constancy of women. Appetitus snoars aloud.beware sirrah, take heed, I doubt me there's some wild boar lodgeth hereabout; how now? methinks these be the senses, ha? in my conceit the elder brother of death has kissed them.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: O, o, o, I am stabbed, I am stabbed, hold your hand, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: How now? do they talk in the sleep? are they not awake Heuresis?

sp.speaker: Heu.
sp.p: No questionless, they be all fast asleep.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Eat not too many of those apples, they be very flative?

sp.speaker: Olf.
sp.p: Foh, foh, beat out this dog here, foh, was it you Appetitus?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: In faith it was most sweetly winded, whosoever it was, the warble is very good, and the horn is excellent.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: Put on man, put on, keep your head warm, 'tis cold.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, st, Heuresis, stir not sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: Shut the door, the pot runs over; sirrah cook, that will be a sweet pastry if you nibble the venison so?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Say you so, is a marrow Pie the Helena of meats? give me't, if I play not Paris hang me; boy, a clean trencher?

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.p: Serve up, serve up; this is a fat rabbit, would I might have the maidenhead of it; come give me the fish there; who hath meddled with these maids? ha?

sp.speaker: Olf.
sp.p: Fie, shut your snuffers closer for shame, 'tis the worst smell that can be.

sp.speaker: Tac
sp.p: O the cramp, the cramp, the cramp, my leg, my leg.

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p: I must abroad presently, reach me my best necklace presently.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Ah Lingua, are you there?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Here, take this rope, and I'll help the leader close with the second bell: fie, fie, there is a goodly peal clean spoilt.

sp.speaker: Vis.
sp.p: I'll lay my life that gentlewoman is painted: well, well, I know it, mark but her nose, do you not see the complexion crack out, I must confess 'tis a good picture.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, fie, I pray you leave, you tickle me so, o, ah, ha, ha, take away your hands, I cannot endure, ah, you tickle me, ah, ha, ha, ha, ah.

sp.speaker: Vis.
sp.p: Hai, rett, rett, rett, now bird now — look about that bush, she trust her thereabouts, — here she is, beware wing Cater, beware wing, avaunt.

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p: Mum, mum, mum, mum.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: St, sirrah take heed you wake her not.

sp.speaker: Heu.
sp.p: I know sir she's fast asleep, for her mouth is shut.

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p: This 'tis to venture upon such uncertainties, to lose so rich a crown to no end, well, well.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, we shall hear anon where she lost her maidenhead, st, boy, my lord vicegerent, and master register are hard by, run quickly,
tell them of this accident, wish them come softly.

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p: Mendacio, never talk farther, I doubt 'tis past recovery, and my robe likewise, I shall never have them again, well, well.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: How? her crown, and her robe, never recover them? hum, wast not said to be left by memory? ha? I conjecture here's some knavery — fast locked with sleep, in good faith. Was that crown and garment yours Lingua?

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p: I marry were they, and that somebody hath felt, and shall feel more, if I live.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: O strange; she answers in her sleep to my question; but how come the senses to strive for it?

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p: Why, I laid upon purpose in their way, that they might fall together by the ears.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: What a strange thing is this?

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 18.
div.stage: The senses, appetitus and lingua asleep . Phantastes, communis sensus, memoria, Anamnestes.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: St, my lord, softly, softly, here's the notablest piece of treason discovered, how say you Lingua set all the senses at odds, she hath confessed it to me in her sleep.

sp.speaker: C●m. S.
sp.p: Is't possible master register! did you ever know any talk in their sleep?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I remember my lord many have done so very oft, but women are troubled, especially with this talking disease, many of them have I heard answer in their dreams, and tell what they did all day awake.

sp.speaker: Anam.
sp.p: By the same token, there was a wanton maid, that being asked by her mother, what such a one did with her so late one night in such a room, she presently said, that —

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Peace you vild rake hell, is such a jest fit for this company, no more I say sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: My lord will you believe your own ears, you shall hear her answer me, as directly and truly as may be. Lingua, what did you with the crown and garments.

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p: I'll tell thee Mendacio.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: She thinks Mendacio speaks to her, mark now, mark how truly she will answer: what say you madam?

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p: I say Phantastes is a foolish transparent gull: a mere fanatic nupson in my imagination not worthy to sit as a judge's assistant.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, how truly and directly she answers.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: Faw, favu, she dreams now, she knows not what she says, I'll try her once again: madam? what remedy can you have for your great losses?

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p:
O are you come Acrasia? welcome, welcome, boy reach a cushion sit down good Acrasia: I am so beholding to you, your potion
wrought exceedingly, the senses were so mad, did not you see how they raged about the woods?

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: Hum, Acrasia? is Acrasia her confederate? my life that witch hath wrought some villainy, —
sp.stage: Lingua viseth in her sleep, and walketh.
sp.p: How's this? is she asleep ? have you seen one walk thus before?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: It is a very common thing, I have seen many sick of a Peripatetic disease.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: By the same token my lord, I knew one that went abroad in his sleep, bent his bow, shot at a magpie, killed her, fetched his arrow, came home, locked the doors, and went to bed again.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: What should be the reason of it?

sp.speaker: Mem
sp.p: I remember Scalliger told me the reason once; as I think thus: the nerves that carry the moving faculty, from the brains, to the thighs, legs, feet, and arms, are wider far than the other nerves; wherefore they are not so easily stopped with the vapours of sleep, but are night and day ready to perform what fancy shall command them.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: It may be so, but Phantastes inquire more of Acrasia.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: What did you with with the potion Acrasia made you.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Gave it to the senses, and made them as mad as — well, if I cannot recover it — let it go, I'll not leave them thus.

sp.speaker: Con. S.
sp.p: Boy awake the senses there.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Ho, ho, Auditus, up, up, so ho, Olfactus have at your nose, up Visus, Gustus, tactus, up: what can you not feel a pinch? have at you with a pin.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: O, you stab me, o.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: Tactus, know you how you came hither?

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.l: No my lord, not I; this I remember,
We supped with Gustus, and had wine good store,
Whereof I think I tasted liberally.
Among the rest, we drunk a composition,
Of a most delicate, and pleasant relish,
That made our brains, somewhat irregular.

div.head: Actus. 4. Scaena. 7.
div.stage: The senses awake, lingua, asleep , communis sensus, memory, Anamnestes, Heuresis drawing Crapula.

sp.speaker: Heu.
sp.p: My lord, here's a fat rascal was lurking in a bush very suspiciously, his name he says is Crapula.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: Sirrah, speak quickly what you know of these troubles.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nothing my lord, but that the senses were mad, and that Somnus at my request laid them asleep , in hope to recover them.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: Why then 'tis too evident, Acrasia at Lingua's request, bewitched the senses, wake her quickly Heuresis.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Heigh ho, out alas, ay me, where am I? how came I here? where am I? ah.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: Lingua look not so strangely upon the matter, you have confessed in your sleep, that with a crown, and a robe, you have disturbed the senses, using a crafty help to enrage them, can you deny it?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Ay me, most miserable wretch, I beseech your lordship forgive me.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis a fault unpardonable.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: In my conceit Lingua, you should seal up your lips, when you go to bed, these feminine tongues be so glib.

sp.speaker: Com. S.
sp.p: Visus, tactus, and the rest, our former sentence concerning you, we confirm as irrevocable, and establish the crown to you Visus, and the robe to you tactus, but as for you Lingua —

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Let me have mine own, howsoever you determine, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Com: S.
sp.p:
That may not be, your goods are fallen into our hands, my sentence cannot be recalled, you may see, those that seek what is not theirs, oftentimes lose what's their own: therefore Lingua granting you your life, I commit you to close prison, in Gustus his house, and charge
you Gustus, to keep her under the custody of two strong doors, and every day till she come to 80. years of age, see she be well guarded with 30. tall watchmen, without whose licence she shall by no means wag abroad; nevertheless use her ladylike, according to her estate.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: I pray you my lord add this to the judgement, that whensoever she obtaineth licence to walk abroad, in token the tongue was the cause of her offence, let her wear a velvet hood, made just in the fashion of a great tongue, in my conceit 'tis a very pretty emblem of a woman.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: My lord, she hath a vild boy to her page, a chief agent in this treason, his name's Mendacio.

sp.speaker: Con. S.
sp.p: Ha? well, I will inflict this punishment on him for this time, let him be soundly whipped, and ever after though he shall strengthen his speeches with the sinews of truth, yet none shall believe him.

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.p: In my imagination my lord, the day is dead to the great toe, and in my conceit it grows dark, by which I conjecture it will be cold; and therefore in my fancy, and opinion, 'tis best to repair to our lodgings.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes, praeter Anamnestes and appetitus.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 20.
div.stage: Anamnestes., Appetitus asleep in a corner.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: What's this? A fellow whispering so closely with the earth? so ho, so ho: Appetitus? faith now I think Morpheus himself hath been here, up with a pox to you, up you lusk, I have such news to tell thee sirrah: all the senses are well, and Lingua is proved guilty, up, up, up, I never knew him so fast asleep in my life.
Nay then have at you a fresh, (Tiff, toff, tiff, toff.)

sp.speaker: App.
sp.p: Jog me once again, and I'll throw this whole mess of pottage in your face, cannot one stand quiet at the dresser for you?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I think it's impossible for him to sleep longer than he dreams of his victuals. What Appetitus, up quickly, quickly up, Appetitus, quickly sirrah, (Toff, toff, toff, toff.)

sp.speaker: App.
sp.p: I'll come presently, but I hope you'll stay till they be roasted, will you eat them raw?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Roasted? ha, ha, ha, ha, up, up, away.

sp.speaker: App,
sp.p: Reach the sauce quickly, here's no sugar, whaw, wam, o, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: What never wake? (Tiff, toff, tiff, toff,) wilt never be? Then I must try another way I see.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: Judicious friends, it is so late at night,
I cannot waken hungry appetite:
Then since the close upon his rising stands,
Let me obtain this at your courteous hands,
Try if the friendly opportunity,
Of your good will and gracious plaudite,
With the thrice welcome murmur it shall keep
Can beg this prisoner from the hands of sleep.
div.stage: Upon the plaudite appetitus awakes, and runs in after Anamnestes

div.head: Courteous reader, these books following are printed and sold by Simon miller, at the star in st. Paul's churchyard.
Large folio.
div.p: Luther's colloquium Mensalia.

div.head: Small folio.
div.p: The civil wars of Spain in the reign of Charles the fifth, emperor of Germany, and King of that nation, where in our late unhappy differences are paralleled in many particulars.

A general history of Scotland, from the year 767. to the death of King James, containing the principal revolutions, and transactions of church and state, with political observations, and reflections upon the same: by David Hume of gods-croft.
The history of this iron age.
Doctor Lightfoot his harmony on the new testament.

div.head: In quarto large.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
